pullRequest.body:
---
<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

For details on the "pull request lifecycle" in mathlib, please see:
https://leanprover-community.github.io/contribute/index.html

In particular, note that most reviewers will only notice your PR
if it passes the continuous integration checks.
Please ask for help on https://leanprover.zulipchat.com if needed.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

If you are moving or deleting declarations, please include these lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Moves:
- Vector.* -> List.Vector.*
- ...

Deletions:
- Nat.bit1_add_bit1
- ...

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]

-->

[![Open in Gitpod](https://gitpod.io/button/open-in-gitpod.svg)](https://gitpod.io/from-referrer/)

nodes.body:
### PR summary [5bf243ad90](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/21137/commits/5bf243ad90f956b70070f61000395f866f0b0b54)

#### Import changes for modified files

No significant changes to the import graph


<details><summary>Import changes for all files</summary>

|Files|Import difference|
|-|-|

</details>

---

#### Declarations diff

`+ single`
<details>
  <summary>You can run this locally as follows</summary>


```bash
## summary with just the declaration names:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh <optional_commit>

## more verbose report:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh long <optional_commit>
```
</details>

The doc-module for `script/declarations_diff.sh` contains some details about this script.

---

<details><summary>No changes to technical debt.</summary>

You can run this locally as
```
./scripts/technical-debt-metrics.sh pr_summary
```
* The `relative` value is the weighted *sum* of the differences with weight given by the *inverse* of the current value of the statistic.
* The `absolute` value is the `relative` value divided by the total sum of the inverses of the current values (i.e. the weighted *average* of the differences).
</details>
Apart from the naming question (where I'm interested in Floris' opinion also), this looks good to me.
maintainer delegate
ðŸš€ Pull request has been placed on the maintainer queue by grunweg.

Thanks!

I also prefer `single`, since `const` would make me think that the two *types* are singletons and the equivalence is constant, rather than that there is a *single* element on which the (partial) equivalence applies.

bors merge

Pull request successfully merged into master.

Build succeeded:
  * [Lint style](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/13075210613/job/36485616712)
  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/13075210613/job/36485617077)
Thanks for your PR! I agree this is useful; I have just a couple of small comments. It may look like a lot, but should be easy to address.

I think we prefer not indenting doc-strings.
```suggestion
It consists of two constant maps in opposite directions. -/

You can write this as
```suggestion
  map_source' _ _ := by rfl
```
(or even just `rfl`), right? Please also make the analogous change to the other fields.
Is there some explicit lemma that `rfl` is calling? Can you try if `rw?` suggests something?

I would call this `PartialEquiv.const`.

I guess you called it like this because of `Pi.single` and friends: I'm not sold by this analogy, because `Pi.single` takes a prescribed value at a point, but value *0* otherwise - this is quite different from what this definition does.
This name was suggested by Floris, so I'm not actually sure about the reasoning. @fpvandoorn

I personally like `single` better, since it's a partial equivalence with a single value. Sure, it's defined to be as `const` outside the domain, but that is not the important part of this definition.
I don't feel strongly, and can live with `const` as well.
Ah, now I understand your motivation. I'm not sure if I prefer single or const, but I don't have a strong opinion, and am fine with either option.

pullRequest.title: [Merged by Bors] - feat: Function.const as a PartialEquiv
